summary: I’m reading the EW/GOT article (I got the Night King cover in the mail 😒) and the caption for The Hound’s photo says, “After...
body:
I’m reading the EW/GOT article (I got the Night King cover in the mail 😒) and the caption for The Hound’s photo says, “After years of servitude, he has joined Team Dany and ‘found a bit of peace,’ says Rory McCann.”

Team Dany = giving the fucking Hound of all people peace and not forcing him into servitude. Now, does that sound like an entitled queen who’s going to go mad with power?

summary: A Potential Parallel Between Daenerys and Her Dragons
title: A Potential Parallel Between Daenerys and Her Dragons
body:
I was working on a post about Braavos when I suddenly realized that Daenerys may share a very interesting parallel with her dragons.

In Fire and Blood, Elissa Farman spirited away three dragon eggs from Dreamfyre’s clutch on Dragonstone and made her way to Braavos where she secured an audience with the Sealord of Braavos, selling him the eggs. Elissa also spent some time in Pentos with the eggs before selling them to the Sealord.

Daenerys Targaryen was born on Dragonstone and was spirited away to Braavos, where a secret marriage pact for her brother was witnessed by the Sealord of Braavos. She also some spends time in Pentos just before the series begins.

If the three dragon eggs Elissa Farman took are Drogon, Rhaegal, and Viserion then I think it’s very fitting that their story bears a resemblance to their mothers.

In Fire and Blood, Elissa Farman spirited away three dragon eggs from Dreamfyre’s clutch on Dragonstone and made her way to Braavos where she secured an audience with the Sealord of Braavos, selling him the eggs. Elissa also spent some time in Pentos with the eggs before selling them to the Sealord.

Daenerys Targaryen was born on Dragonstone and was spirited away to Braavos, where a secret marriage pact for her brother was witnessed by the Sealord of Braavos. She also some spends time in Pentos just before the series begins.

If the three dragon eggs Elissa Farman took are Drogon, Rhaegal, and Viserion then I think it’s very fitting that their story bears a resemblance to their mothers.

summary: daenerys does not have albinism. y'all need to stop dodging the conversation about her status as a white savior by claiming...
question: daenerys does not have albinism. y'all need to stop dodging the conversation about her status as a white savior by claiming she's disabled when she's not. grrm chose to give targaryens purple eyes to distinguish them from other houses. when he gives a character albinism, he gives them red eyes. just stop it already.
answer:
Did you know that the only people ON THE FACE OF THE PLANET with purple eyes are people with albinism?

Do you honestly think that is a coincidence? I don’t. 

I’ve gone my whole life without ever seeing a character that looks like me in film/TV. Until now. Oh, and these people who look like me also have stereotypical themes that match stereotypes related to albinism:

1. Association with magic

2. Having silver hair/purple eyes that is recessive and runs in families

3. Having a pure/weird bloodline

4. Association with volcanos/caves

5. Being presented as evil, the villain, or mad/insane

6. Having magical blood

The use of that characteristic was not to only distinguish them from other houses. I have listed plenty of other stereotypes relating to albinism that are also associated with Targaryens. I think you’re just threatened because my point of view on this takes away your Performative Woke Points. Y’all never considered that there are minorities out there that you know nothing about. 

Grrm’s treatment of characters that he calls albino is similarly stereotypical and they also happen to be Targaryen. What do you know! Bloodraven’s character, for example, is a walking albinism stereotype and a Targaryen. 

No one is saying you can’t discuss the white savior trope in relation to her character. You can look through every post I’ve made on this hell site and you won’t find a single one claiming Daenerys is immune somehow form that observation. I also don’t care if you hate her character. Or if you hate Jon/Daenerys as a ship. I agree that GRRM has issues with how he portrays Dany in Mereen and the occupants of slaver’s bay/Essos. 

But what y’all do not seem to understand is that people with Daenerys phenotype (pale skin, purple eyes, and silvery blonde hair) can also be other races. People of color with albinism have that same phenotype, and I think that point is relevant when there are SO MANY common stereotypes shared between albinism and the Targaryens. So when you do these critiques of this character it actually requires some nuance, because Dany’s appearance does not automatically code as white. 

Every time I bring up that point the argument breaks down from these Jonsa Performative Social Justice fans because you can’t distinguish between “white person with pale skin” and “person who looks like they have albinism.”

summary: Game of Thrones | 1.10 "Fire and Blood" The black-and-scarlet beast was draped across her shoulders, its long sinuous neck...
caption:
Game of Thrones | 1.10 “Fire and Blood”
The black-and-scarlet beast was draped across her shoulders, its long sinuous neck coiled under her chin. When it saw Jorah, it raised its head and looked at him with eyes as red as coals.

tags: evil dany believers are gonna be in shock when s8 aires
summary: People who see the potential for Dark Dany aren’t completely off-base honestly. The themes are there. The scenarios are there....
body:
People who see the potential for Dark Dany aren’t completely off-base honestly. The themes are there. The scenarios are there. But the crucial difference is Dany doesn’t take that route. You’re supposed to see the villain tropes, and then watch how Dany defies them. In order for her arc to have more meaning, there has to be the potential for darkness.

And I think the same can be said, albeit less obvious, with Jon Snow.
